item.title: France Unsure if Raid Killed Top Suspect in Paris Attacks
item.description: Two people were killed and more than 5,000 rounds were fired in the raid near Paris, but officials were not sure if the suspected ringleader of the attacks was there.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE, LIZ ALDERMAN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of a raid in St.-Denis, north of Paris, on Wednesday. The raid was aimed at detaining a Belgian militant suspected of organizing the attacks in Paris on Friday that killed 129 people.

item.title: Paris Attacks Highlight Jihadists’ Easy Path Between Europe and ISIS Territory
item.description: It appears that as many as six of the attackers identified in the Paris massacre were Europeans who traveled to fight and train in Syria before returning home.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Boko Haram Ranked Ahead of ISIS for Deadliest Terror Group
item.description: A new report tracking terrorist attacks around the world said the Nigerian militant group was responsible for nearly 600 more deaths last year than the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and MARC SANTORA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Fresh Doubt Over China’s Pledge to Amend Transplant Policy
item.description: Some disagree, saying that there has been a surge in voluntary donations as China announced it would end organ harvesting from death-row prisoners.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Doctors performing surgery on a patient at a hospital in Tianjin. China is trying to change its organ transplant system to bring it more in line with international standards.

item.title: News Analysis: For France, an Alliance Against ISIS May Be Easier Said Than Done
item.description: France wants a coalition in its war on ISIS, but disagreements between Russian and American leaders are undermining cooperation against a common enemy.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France, center, with Prime Minister Manuel Valls at the Elysee Palace in Paris on Wednesday. Mr. Hollande is trying to show diplomatic initiative although he under pressure at home to act strongly against the Islamic State.

item.title: French Return to Cafes in a Show of Defiance
item.description: The most typical of Parisian scenes — sharing drinks among friends — became a show of defiance after the terrorist attacks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: ​Many ​Parisians ​say they returned to the​ city's​ cafes quickly after ​last week's​ terrorist attacks to prove that the​ir way of life could not be threatened.

item.title: Strikes on Raqqa in Syria Lead to More Questions Than Results
item.description: The strategy is renewing a debate about how effective such attacks can be in defeating the Islamic State, without measures like drying up its financial support or conducting a ground assault.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The French Army began airstrikes on Sunday night against the Islamic State in Raqqa, the militants’ de facto capital in Syria.

item.title: Join the Debate: How Should We Balance Civil Liberties and National Security?
item.description: We would like to hear from you.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Increased security in front of the Louvre museum in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Police in China Kill 17 Linked to Mine Attack, Report Says
item.description: The dead, including women and children, were said to have been involved in a knife attack in September that left 50 people dead at a mine near the Kyrgyzstan border.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Editorial Observer: The Poignancy of the Paris Targets
item.description: The terrorists attacked the places — restaurants, cafes — where private life flows freely into the public space.
item.dc:creator: MIRA KAMDAR
item.media:description: Mourners outside "Le Petit Cambodge" and "Le Carillon" restaurants in Paris.

item.title: Refugees Across Europe Fear Repercussions From Paris Attacks
item.description: After fleeing their homeland to escape war and Islamist extremism, many now find that their long trek to the Continent may offer no guarantee of protection.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and KIMBERLY BRADLEY
item.media:description: Migrants and refugees waited outside a registration camp on Wednesday after crossing the Greece-Macedonia border near Gevgelija, Macedonia.

item.title: Bartica Journal: In Guyana, a Land Dispute With Venezuela Escalates Over Oil
item.description: Venezuela has long insisted it owns everything west of the Essequibo River, including the Guyanese town of Bartica, a battle that intensified after an oil discovery.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A military parade this month in Georgetown, the capital of Guyana.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What Middle Class Means in Malaysia
item.description: A long drive for prosperity is giving way to a debate about how the country shares its wealth.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW
item.media:description: A beggar in central Kuala Lumpur.

item.title: Thailand Deports 2 Dissidents to China, Rights Groups Say
item.description: The dissidents had won official recognition as refugees and had been previously detained in China for their activism.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: After Myanmar Election, Few Signs of a Better Life for Muslims
item.description: Experts said they expected no drastic changes in government policies toward Muslims, but they held out hope that things at least would not become worse.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A Muslim voter casting her vote at a polling station in Yangon, Myanmar, on Nov. 8.

item.title: Assailants in Bangladesh Attack Catholic Missionary
item.description: The missionary, Piero Parolari, who was wounded, is an Italian physician who has lived in the northern region of the country for more than 30 years.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: State of Terror: In Rise of ISIS, No Single Missed Key but Many Strands of Blame
item.description: By the time the U.S. withdrew from Iraq, it thought it had subdued the Islamic State. The group is now on a very different trajectory.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER
item.media:description: An image taken from a video uploaded by the Islamic State showing fighters last year near Tikrit, Iraq.

item.title: Obama Calls on Beijing to Stop Construction in South China Sea
item.description: In the Philippines for an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit, President Obama urged China to halt military activities on the disputed islands.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama speaking Wednesday at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting in Manila, where he discussed China, trade and climate change.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Is Any Place Safe?
item.description: France has been wounded. The solution is not to become like its enemies.
item.dc:creator: ABDELLAH TAÏA

item.title: Letter From Europe: Culture Shock in the Promised Land of Germany
item.description: The nation’s challenge of integrating over a million migrants goes beyond teaching them German and finding jobs. It’s also about easing culture shock.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teenage refugees from Afghanistan at an art class in Passau, Germany. The German government pays for refugee “integration classes,” and many schools conduct “welcome classes” for refugee children, teaching them not just the language but about life and values in Germany.
